title: Amazon expands in-store pickup service Counter to GNC, Health Mart and Stage Stores
text:
CLOSE Gita a robot that can follow you and carry 40 lbs worth of stuff. Josmar Taveras, USA TODAY

In a move that conveniently edges Amazon further into the health care space, the e-commerce giant just announced that it's partnering with the nutrition brand GNC, pharmacy network Health Mart and retailer Stage Stores to give you greater control over how you retrieve your packages.

Just months after Amazon introduced in-store pickup options to Rite Aids in the U.S., the online retailer said on Wednesday it is significantly expanding its reach into more than 1,000 new stores by 2020.

Shoppers can currently pick up their packages at 100 Right Aid stores, but by the end of the year, that number will swell to 1,500 GNC, Health Mart and Stage Stores stores "from Oyster Bay, N.Y., to Chula Vista, Calif," Amazon said.

The pickup service is called Amazon Counter and it lets you ship your packages to the nearest partnering store if you fear your neighbor, or strangers, will steal your packaged delivery before you can make it home from work.

Many product searches now start on Amazon, not Google. (Photo: Amazon)

Amazon said it leveraged its "growing logistics network and invested in new, easy to use technology to give customers yet another delivery option rooted in flexibility and control."

How Counter works

When you try to make a purchase online or using the Amazon app, you'll see an option to ship to one of the Counter pickup points in your ZIP code.

(Photo: Amazon)

Once your package arrives at a partnering location, you'll get an email and unique barcode to retrieve your goods during store hours.

The option is just one of Amazon's Hub services which include Lockers, a self-service kiosk that lets you pick up your package at a time that's convenient for you. Amazon also offers Key, an in-home delivery service where drivers can drop packages inside your home near the front door.

Amazon has launched a telemedicine smartphone app for some Seattle-based employees. The news dented Teladoc's share price, but not as badly as it might have. (Photo: Andrei Stanescu / Getty Images)

Amazon and health care

Partnering with two health-related brands like GNC and Health Mart may not just be by happenstance. Amazon has dropped hints about moving into healthcare for years.

In 2018, Amazon launched a company to reduce health care costs for employees along with Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase. That same year, Amazon acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy the lets users buy medications in prepackaged doses.

Last month, the online retailer launched Amazon Care, a virtual health clinic for Amazon employees in Seattle.
